responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Potential command injection in run-queued-jobs.sh
    analysis: |
      The run-queued-jobs.sh script passes the output of inotifywait directly to sh without any validation or sanitization. This allows an attacker to inject arbitrary commands by manipulating the name of a job file in the $SILVERSTRIPE_CACHE/queuedjobs directory.

      For example, if an attacker creates a file named "test; rm -rf /", the resulting command executed would be:
      php $SILVERSTRIPE_ROOT/framework/cli-script.php dev/tasks/ProcessJobQueueTask job=test; rm -rf /
      
      This would execute the ProcessJobQueueTask but then also recursively delete files starting from the root directory.

      Any user with write access to the $SILVERSTRIPE_CACHE/queuedjobs directory can exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary commands on the server with the privileges of the user running the run-queued-jobs.sh script.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - scripts/run-queued-jobs.sh
    classification: very promising

```

leads.headline: Potential command injection in run-queued-jobs.sh
leads.analysis:
The run-queued-jobs.sh script passes the output of inotifywait directly to sh without any validation or sanitization. This allows an attacker to inject arbitrary commands by manipulating the name of a job file in the $SILVERSTRIPE_CACHE/queuedjobs directory.

For example, if an attacker creates a file named "test; rm -rf /", the resulting command executed would be:
php $SILVERSTRIPE_ROOT/framework/cli-script.php dev/tasks/ProcessJobQueueTask job=test; rm -rf /

This would execute the ProcessJobQueueTask but then also recursively delete files starting from the root directory.

Any user with write access to the $SILVERSTRIPE_CACHE/queuedjobs directory can exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary commands on the server with the privileges of the user running the run-queued-jobs.sh script.
